--- title: Cillian McHugh title-block-banner: "files/20210214_162331.jpg" title-block-style: default about: template: solana image-width: 12em image-shape: round image: files/avatar1.jpg # links: # - icon: globe # # text: Web # href: www.cillianmchugh.com # - icon: github # # text: Github # href: https://github.com/cillianmiltown # - icon: twitter # # text: Twitter # href: https://twitter.com/CillianMacAodh # - icon: mastodon # # text: Mastodon # href: https://mastodon.ie/@cillianmchugh # # - icon: linkedin # # text: LinkedIn # # href: https://www.linkedin.com/in/andreashandel/ # - icon: google-scholar # text: Google Scholar # href: https://scholar.google.com/citations?hl=en&user=OInfWlkAAAAJ # # - icon: impactstory # # text: ImpactStory # # href: https://impactstory.org/u/0000-0002-4622-1146 # - icon: orcid # text: ORCID # href: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9701-3232 comments: false format: html: page-layout: full css: styles_home.css --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Background I am an Experimental Psychologist specialising in cognitive and social psychology. I have worked with a diverse range of research techniques, and I have applied experience in the development of new methods and materials, and in theory development. The main focus of my research to date has been on morality and moral judgement. I have applied understandings from the cognitive psychology of concepts and categories to the moral domain to propose a novel theory of [*Moral Judgment as Categorization (MJAC)*](https://www.cillianmchugh.com/publication/moral-judgment-as-categorization). My empirical work has largely focused on the phenomenon of [moral dumbfounding](https://www.cillianmchugh.com/publication/searching-for-moral-dumbfounding/); when a person defends a moral judgement in the absence of reasons. The dumbfounding paradigm has been influential in moral psychology; however, there has been limited empirical work investigating it. This has meant that the main focus of my work to date has been testing, and attempting to understand the phenomenon. My interests extend beyond the moral domain to include learning and knowledge acquisition, categorisation, skill/expertise, meaning, motivation, and memory. My theoretical interests include Ecological Psychology, Embodiment, and Dynamical Systems. ## Featured Video Moral Judgment as Categorization (MJAC): presentation to IMP seminar series 31st May 2021 ```{=html}
